p: Understanding the connection between infectious diseases and climate is difficult because of the multivariate nature of climate change and non-linear thresholds in both disease and climate change processes. It is commonly assumed that the distribution of infectious diseases is determined by climate and that the present climate change will increase their incidence and geographic distribution. Consequently, the relationship between temperature and the transmission of pathogens has gained substantial attention ( 8). However, just because a vector species can transmit a certain pathogen in one geographical area, that does not necessarily mean that the populations of the same species are competent hosts for the same pathogen in another geographic location ( 9) as the vector competence of mosquitoes can be influenced by both temperature and viral genetics ( 8).
